title.narrative: World Bank Umbrella Facility for Trade 2017-2023
World Bank Umbrella Facility for Trade 2017-2023

description.narrative:
Nytt stöd till Världsbanksgruppens nya övergripande handelsfond, "Umbrella Facility for Trade" (UF-Trade). UF-Trade avser ersätta tidigare multigivarfonder utifrån en heltäckande handelsstrategi och ett sammanhängande resultatramverk.
Världsbanksgruppen med sitt mandat och stora kapacitet har möjlighet att ta ett helhetsgrepp kring handelsrelaterat utvecklingssamarbete. Genom policypåverkan, analyser, implementering samt finansiering har de förutsättningar som ingen annan aktör har.
UF-Trade bygger fortsatt på Världsbanksgruppens handelsstrategi och dess tematiska områden. Dessa är: i) konkurrenskraft och diversifiering; ii) handelsprocedurer, logistik och handelsfinansiering; iii) stöd för marknadstillträde och internationellt handelssamarbete; samt iv) hantering av chocker och stärkt inkluderande fattigdomsminskning. Utöver dessa har globala värdekedjor, regional integration och tjänstehandel identifierats som högprioriterade områden. Dessa liksom ett ökat fokus på bland annat jämställdhetsfrågor utgör ett tematiskt fönster som fördelas enligt:
- Regionala och nationella insatser - "just-in-time" för hastigt uppkomna behov - globala frågor såsom forskning, påverkansarbete och framtagandet av olika verktyg
Världsbanksgruppen har presenterat ett förslag på arbetsområden och aktiviteter under sex år med en totalt önskad budget på 180 miljoner USD. Svenskt stöd till UF-Trade föreslås med 90 miljoner SEK för initialt tre år. För de tre första åren är finansiering på ungefär 45-50 miljoner USD utlovade av Sverige, Nederländerna, Storbritannien, Schweiz och Norge vilket innebär att UF-Trade idag är underfinansierat gentemot önskad budget. Finansieringen för de avslutande tre åren kan vara avhängigt ytterligare givare samt resultat under de första åren.
Medlen ska fördelas på olika "kuvert" eller finansieringsfönster enligt följande fördelning:
1. Regionalt och nationellt arbete som kommer innebära majoriteten av aktiviteter beräknas erhålla 65% av tillgängliga medel. 2. Globala frågor och insatser relaterat till forskning, påverkansarbete globalt samt metod- och verktygsutveckling får 30% av tillgängliga medel. 3. Det sista fönstret som benämns "just-in-time" ger utrymme för hastigt uppkomna behov och till det avsätts högst 5% av budgeten.
Givarna har också kommit överens med Banken att 60% av tillgängliga medel ska fokuseras på Afrika söder om Sahara och andra låginkomstländer.
Då den övergripande budgeten utgör en grund för projekt och programprioriteringar finns ingen detaljerad budget för hela fonden vilket är normalt för en trust fund på exempelvis Världsbanken. Däremot finns det kriterier och tematiska prioriteringar för vad medlen får användas till. Majoriteten av pengarna går till analytiskt arbete i form av studier och behovsanalyser, forskning, utveckling av verktyg och indikatorer. Det sker som nämnts på nationell, regional och global nivå där användandet kan vara normativt eller bidra till global dialog eller som underlag för vidare implementering av större gåvo eller låneprojekt. Världsbanksgruppens administrationskostnad baseras på en standard på 17%.
Inom UF-Trade kommer ett fönster finansiera aktiviteter under Världbanksgruppens "Trade Facilitation Support Program" (TFSP). TFSP:s funktion är att hjälpa utvecklingsländer med implementeringen av WTO:s Trade Facilitation Agreement. Det innebär att förenkla tull- och handelsprocedurer för att sänka transport- och transaktionskostnader i gränsöverskridande handel vilket utgör ett stort bekymmer för många utvecklingsländer. Utöver ovan nämnda givare bidrar även USA, Kanada och EU till TFSP som i dagsläget har en total budget på 36 MUSD. Sverige föreslår att 15 MSEK av det totala stödet till UF-Trade öronmärks till TFSP.
Mot bakgrund att den inte finns en detaljerad budget i detta skedde anser Sida ändå att budgeten framstår som rimlig och berättigad samt att det finns en systematik för hanteringen av budgetfrågor både på projektnivå och aggregerad nivå. Givarna har också möjlighet att påverka styrningen av budgeten i dialog med Världsbanksgruppen.
Sida och Världbanksgruppen avser använda avtalsmallen för multigivarfonder som förhandlades med Världsbanken inom CGOP, med justeringar för att innefatta International Finance Corporation IFC. Både Världsbanken och IFC skriver under avtalet.
Support to World Bank Umbrella Trust Fund for Trade. Will replace existing trust funds under the World Bank Trade Strategy and with one integrated results framework.

The intended effect of the development contribution is based on the World Bank group's "twin goals" to increase shared prosperity, and the eradication of extreme poverty. According to the theory of change, more and better jobs, increased trade flows and raised productivity, contribute to increased incomes and to achieve these goals. The World Bank Group analysis underpinning this theory of change, identifies a number of challenges that limit the possibilities of achieving these goals. Examples of challenges include weak diversification, high transaction and trading costs, limited market access, and the poor being those who are hardest hit by trade shocks and exclusion. Through a number of different activities at both the country and the global level, the World Bank Group contributes to creating more competitive and open markets, export diversification, reduce trading costs, strengthened capacity in policy making and, not least, an increased and upgraded participation in global value chains. Activities supported include analyzes and research, technical assistance, development of methods and tools, and the establishment of partnerships and dialogues. In the medium / long term, everyone benefits from increased trade and reduced costs. It can be via employment, higher income, reduced consumption costs due to lower prices or improved social services due to stronger public finances. The Sida's contribution aims at supporting the WB implementing its trade strategy which focuses on four main pillars which are: i) trade competitiveness and diversification; ii) trade facilitation and transport logistics; iii) market access and international trade cooperation; and, iv) managing shocks and promoting greater inclusion.

tag.narrative: 17.11 - Avsevärt öka utvecklingsländernas export, i synnerhet i syfte att fördubbla de minst utvecklade ländernas andel av den globala exporten till 2020
17.11 - Significantly increase the exports of developing countries, in particular with a view to doubling the least developed countries’ share of global exports by 2020.

description.narrative:
Trade has historically been an engine of growth that creates jobs, reduces poverty, and increases economic opportunity. Trade is also a pathway to decreasing inequality, improving womens access to skills and education, and supporting womens economic empowerment. Leveraging support from its development partners, the World Bank Group (WBG) has been redoubling its efforts to advance policies that help all countries use trade for green, resilient, and inclusive development. The ultimate goals of the Umbrella Facility for Trade Trust Fund (UF) are to: i) increase the number of WBG projects that incorporate trade; ii) expand the testing, experimentation, research, and sharing of new ideas on trade; iii) gather, document, and disseminate results, data, and knowledge on trade-related issues; and iv) increase the WBGs voice on global trade issues through enhanced global partnerships and engagements. This will lead to enhancing developing countries participation in the global trading system.
Since inception, and as of June 30, 2021, 244 activities have been launched in almost 130 countries with support from the UF. These have been in line with the World Banks four pillars of strategies. More specifically 18% of UFT grants have been allocated towards managing shocks and promoting inclusion, 21% towards trade facilitation and logistics, 24% support for market access and international trade cooperation and lastly 37% towards trade competitiveness and diversification. Against these four pillars country assistance can be regionally divided where 44% is allocated in sub-Saharan Africa, 15% in Latina America including the Caribbean and 14% in East Asia and the Pacific. In regards to SIDAs strategical dimensions the UFT can be related to global/normative, national/institutional as well as bilateral levels. Examples include, but are not limited to, the following; Global/Regional/Normative a) Gender: In FY21, 28 grants in the portfolio addressed gender issues and 49 activities directly addressed trade and poverty. Examples of UF-supported activities in FY21 with a gender component included analysis aimed to strengthening female consumers and suppliers to policy notes of the effects that the COVID-19 pandemic has had on small cross border trade proving the struggles facing female cross-border traders. Also, in FY21, the WBG in collaboration with WTO finalized a Trade and Gender flagship report - Women and Trade: The Role of Trade in Promoting Womens Equality. (glob/norm) b) Enhancing regional trade integration: The UF has supported activities that assess the potential impacts of trade reforms, such as unilateral tariff changes, bilateral or regional preferential trade agreements (PTAs), and other major regional initiatives on gross domestic product (GDP), output, trade, wages, and employment, as well as on sectoral reallocation and adjustment costs, poverty, and income distribution. For example, in FY21 the WBG provided support in all stages of the AfCFTA process (diagnostics; solution design; implementation and monitoring) and is currently actively supporting more than 20 countries to successfully implement the AfCFTA (glob/norm/reg). c) MENA region: Many background papers were produced that reached wide external and internal audiences in the MENA region. These analysis have generated novel empirical research which increases the understanding of the role of digital technologies in the region and in economic development and structural transformation of countries. Together these will contribute to The Upside of Digital in the Middle East and Africa flagship report aimed at providing an analysis of the large benefits a new economic agenda could have in MENA countries (reg/norm). d) Adressing climate change: The UF has supported activities that aim to identify key policy steps that both developed and developing countries can take to ensure that trade plays its full role in supporting the transition to a low-carbon future. With support from the UF, a report on the Urgency and Opportunities for Developing Countries was finalized in FY21 including a review of critical issues within green trade (glob/norm). e) Supporting economic recovery from COVID-19: The UF has supported analytical work aimed at assessing the effects that the pandemic has had on international trade, shipping and global value chains. This had been done by analysing monthly global trends in trade and shipping, identifying post-pandemic opportunities for countries, analysis of reshaping global value chains and an analysis of tourism recovery. It has further aimed at Sammanfattande resultatuppdatering Conclusion on Performance Contribution ID: 61050115 3 (13) supporting conflict affected states such as Burundi and Democratic Republic of Congo (glob/norm). National Processes/Institutions/Beneficiaries a) Somalia adopted a new National Trade Strategy in 2021 which was informed by a WBG diagnostics. This document explicitly states that joining the World Trade Organisation (WTO) is a trade policy priority. The new strategy is aimed at strengthening Somalias trade performance, including in the context of WTO accession. b) In Mozambique a Country Economic Memorandum (CEM), Reigniting Growth for All, was completed in April 2021 as a means of informing how trade can enhance growth in the country and how this growth can be sustained. The report has made important contributions to the countrys 10-year National Development Strategy that the government is currently preparing. In addition, policy notes on inclusive growth were delivered and used to influence policy through dialogue with the Government of Mozambique and a wide range of stakeholders. Areas of focus included agricultural productivity, export diversification in especially services and firm performance. c) In Ethiopia a National Logistics Performance report was finalized by the government in June 2021 with contributions from the WBG supported under the UF. An Ethiopia Logistics Sector Donor Group was also established in the reporting period. The WBG was one of the founding members of the group, which meets monthly to share information on logistics sector developments and programs. The goal of this activity was to assess the implications of, and frame strategic directions for, reforming the regulatory regime of the trade logistics sector in Ethiopia and its vulnerability to the effects of COVID-19. d) A policy note on costs and benefits of Pakistans accession to the WTO Information Technology Agreement (ITA) was finalized and shared with the Pakistanese government. The analysis highlighted the powerful growth effects that adoption of the ITA would have on the Pakistani economy. The adoption would for example lead to a 1.3 percent GDP growth after 10 years. Furthermore, in Pakistan the lack of available safe transport and digital trade have hindered female labour force participation, this note also aimed at narrowing this gender gap by addressing these issues in order for females to participate in the labour force without having to leave their homes. e) The UF has provided technical assistance in order to help Colombia deepen its integration in global markets and better use trade as a engine of growth and the Colombian government during the Colombia Internationalization Mission. A policy note on integration in the global economy as an avenue for post-pandemic growth in Colombia was finalized in 2021. The note included benefits of integration through trade, discussions of Colombias current participation in the global economy and proposes key policy reforms that facilitate Colombia in taking full advantage of further integration activities. The work also contributed to the development of a strategy for post-pandemic Sammanfattande resultatuppdatering Conclusion on Performance Contribution ID: 61050115 4 (13) economic recovery, growth and inclusion that was launched by the Colombian government on August 9, 2021. The government is now working on the actions that are needed to implement the roadmap of reforms that were proposed by the policy note.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
